case_name: Kumaon Motorowners Union Limited v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 486 and 487 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 486 and 487 of 1965. Appeals from the judgments dated the March 12, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 4308 of 1965 and 4309 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeals from judgments dated March 12, 1965 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 4308 of 1965 and 4309 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments dated the March 12, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 4308 of 1965 and 4309 of 1965. S. Pathak, B. Dutta, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant Kumaon Motorowners Union Limited established in 1939 with 330 members owning transport vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Kumaon Motorowners Union Limited  hereinafter referred to as the union  was established in 1939 and had at the date of the writ petitions. 330 members all of whom owned transport vehicles.

facts.text: Union members have public carrier permits and stage carriage permits valid up to 1966 and 1967 in Kumaon region except certain routes.

anchor.surface_text: These members have public carrier permits as well as stage carriage permits, which are in force in the Kumaon region except on certain numberified routes. The permits of the various members of the union are valid upto various dates falling in the years 1966 and 1967.

facts.text: State Government issued notification on August 17, 1964 under cls. gg and i of sub-rule 2 of r. 131 of Defence of India Rules, 1962 prohibiting private operators from plying vehicles on Tanakpur-Dharchula route from October 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1964, the State Government purporting to exer- cise powers under cls.  gg  and  i  of sub-rule  2  of r. 131 of the Defence of India Rules, 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  issued a numberification by which it was directed that with effect from October 1, 1964, numberprivate operators shall ply any vehicle

facts.text: Notification directed that only U.P. Government Roadways vehicles shall ply on Tanakpur-Dharchula route for carriage of persons and goods.

anchor.surface_text: , or class of vehicles for the carriage of persons or goods on, and numbervehicle or class of vehicles operated by the private operators shall pass through, Tanakpur-Dharchula route of Kumaon region. It was further directed in the numberification that on this route, the U.P. Government Roadways vehicles alone shall ply for the carriage persons and goods.

facts.text: Notification stopped plying of all vehicles belonging to union members on Tanakpur-Dharchula route leading to filing of two writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: This result of this numberification was to stop plying of all vehicles belonging to the members of the union on, the route in question and this led to the filing of the two petitions in the High Court. The union was party to both the petitions, which were in the same terms.

facts.text: Petitioners challenged notification on grounds including beyond power under r.131(2)(gg) and (i), mala fide to circumvent Ch.IV-A Motor Vehicles Act, contravention of s.44 Defence of India Act, absence of necessary satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: In the petitions the appellants challenged the numberification of August 17, 1964, and this challenge was based on four grounds. In the first place, it was companytended that numberorder of the kind passed on August 17, 1964 companyld be passed under r. 131  2   gg  and  i . In the second place, it was companytended that the U.P. Government was companytemplating nationalisation of this route in the Kumaon region for a long time prior to August 1964.

facts.text: State Government considered nationalisation of route prior to August 1964 but justified order due to reports since 1960 of anti-national elements infiltrating transport organisation.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed that at one time prior to August 1964 the State Sup C1166-9 Government had thought of nationalizing this route and this matter was under companysideration for sometime since 1962. But the State Government justified the passing of the impugned order on the ground that since 1960 reports had started companying in from the State Intelligence Department that certain anti-national and subversive elements were infiltrating the transport Organisation

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner Almora sent report in October 1960 that no new routes in Pithoragarh should be given to union for national security.

anchor.surface_text: As far back as October 1960, the Deputy Commissioner, Almora had sent a report to Government that it was necessary in the interest of national security that, numbernew routes in Pithoragarh should be given for operation to the union and that their operation should be limited to Almora proper.

facts.text: Meeting of high officials on November 14, 1960 decided to eliminate anti-national elements from transport organisation.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon in a meeting of high officials on November 14, 1960, it was decided that the Deputy Inspector General Intelligence, should supply the Transport Commissioner with a list of the ring leaders of such anti-national elements, and the Transport Commissioner should make efforts for the elimination of such elements from the transport Organisation.

facts.text: Further meetings held in January and August 1961 on eliminating undesirable elements.

anchor.surface_text: Further meetings were held in January and August 1961 in which it was pointed out that it was difficult to eliminate undesirable elements from transport organizations on account of existing labour laws.

facts.text: In May 1962, State Government tentatively decided operation of transport in border areas by Government alone.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in May 1962, it was tentatively decided by the State Government that the real solution to the problem lay in the operation of transport in the border areas by Government alone.

facts.text: Chinese attacked in October 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This was the, situation when the Chinese attacked in October 1962.

facts.text: In November 1962, an employee of the union detained under r.30(1)(b) of Rules.

anchor.surface_text: In November 1962, an employee of the union had to be detained under r. 30  1   b  of the Rules as his activities were companysidered prejudicial to the defence of India and public safety.

facts.text: Chief Minister finally decided in July 1964 to take route from private operators for security.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it was finally decided in August 1964 after the matter was put up before the Chief Minister who dealt with matters arising out of the Act and the Rules that in the interest of security, this route should be taken away from private operators like the union and that the transport department should run its own vehicles on it. It was in companysequence of this decision of the Chief Minister finally made in July 1964

facts.text: High Court negatived all contentions of appellants and dismissed petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived all the companytentions raised on behalf of the appellants. As to the satisfaction of the Chief Minister before the issue of the impugned order, the High Court was of the view that the affidavit filed on behalf of the State Government was number very satisfactory but on the whole it came to the companyclusion that the order had been issued after the necessary satisfaction and companysequently the petitions were dismissed.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificates from High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then obtained certificates from the High Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court affidavit filed on August 16, 1965 by Deputy Secretary Home Department stating Chief Minister's satisfaction on July 30, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we gave an opportunity to the State Government to file an affidavit to show that the satisfaction of the State Government necessary before passing an order of this kind was arrived at. In companysequence an affidavit was filed on behalf of the State Government on August 16, 1965 by the Deputy Secretary  Home Department  U.P. Government, Lucknow.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.

arguments.claim: s.43 DIA prevails over s.68B MVA as later, emergency legislation with emphatic language

anchor.surface_text: This argument is met on behalf of the State by reference to S. 43 of the Act which lays down that the provisions of this Act or any rule made thereunder or any order made under any such rule

arguments.claim: s.6(4) DIA does not make entire MVA part of DIA

anchor.surface_text: The words shall have effect appearing in s. 6 (4) of the Act have to be read in the context of that sub-section. In that context they only mean that the Motor Vehicles Act will continue as before

holdings.text: The impugned order is within the powers of the State Government under r.131(2)(gg) and (i) of the Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the order passed by the State Government on August 17, 1964 was within its powers under r., 131  2   gg  and  i  of the Rules. This brings us to the question of mala fides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vehicles cannot be divorced from operators; s.43 DIA overrides MVA Ch.IV-A; no destruction of undertaking; cl.(i) fills vacuum created by prohibition under (gg).

holdings.text: s.43 of the Defence of India Act prevails over s.68B of the Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that s. 43 of the Act must prevail. In the first place, s. 43 appears in an Act which is later than the Motor Vehicles Act and therefore in such a situation unless there is anything repugnant,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Later emergency legislation with more emphatic overriding language; object to meet national emergency.

holdings.text: r.131(2)(gg) empowers prohibition on persons plying vehicles, not just inanimate vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: But we are of opinion that the vehicles, the companytrol of which is envisaged in cl.  gg , cannot be divorced from the persons who are plying the vehicles. No order can be issued to vehicles which

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vehicles inanimate; orders must address persons plying them to achieve clause purposes.

holdings.text: Impugned order does not destroy commercial undertaking of the union.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that in this case there is numberdestruction of the companymercial undertaking of the union, for the simple reason that it is number disputed that this is number the only route on which the union is plying its vehicles

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affects only one route; no takeover of assets; merely prohibits plying on specific route, reducing but not destroying profit capacity.

holdings.text: Second part of order directing U.P. Govt Roadways to ply falls under r.131(2)(i).

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the vacuum was filled by the Roadways, because that Organisation was readily available to Government to fill it. Otherwise we have numberdoubt that the Government companyld have made some other arrangement to fill the vacuum.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.(i) complementary to (gg); authorizes provisions to fill vacuum in transport on prohibited route.

holdings.text: s.6(4) DIA does not incorporate entire Motor Vehicles Act into DIA or limit s.43.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is numberforce in this argument. The words shall have effect appearing in s. 6 4  of the Act have to be read in the companytext of that sub-section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'shall have effect' mean MVA continues subject to specified amendments only, not entire Act part of DIA.

holdings.text: No mala fides; order not device to circumvent Ch.IV-A MVA.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that there is numberquestion of the order being mala fide or having been passed as a device to avoid payment of companypensation under Ch. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on genuine security concerns from 1960 reports and Chinese invasion; alternatives explored over 4 years.

holdings.text: Order does not contravene s.44 DIA.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are number prepared to hold that the order in question interferes with the rights of the appellants more than was necessary for the purpose to be attained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minimal interference principle; petitioners fail to show less intrusive alternative; prior attempts unsuccessful.

holdings.text: Necessary subjective satisfaction of State Government existed before issuing order.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this affidavit filed in this Court there can be numberdoubt that the necessary satisfaction of the State Government which is a companydition precedent for the issue of an order under the rules was there

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.
The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeals fail and are dismissed; no relief granted to appellants upholding the impugned order and High Court judgment
